snippet: An appeals panel said the court needed time to consider the larger issues surrounding the death sentence of a man whose lawyers say he suffered from schizophrenia for years before killing his in-laws.
abstract: Three-judge panel of United States Court of Appeals in New Orleans stays execution of Texas prisoner Scott Panetti, who shot his wife's parents to death in 1992, saying court needs more time to weigh larger mental health issues in case; Panetti's lawyers argue he suffered from schizophrenia for more than 30 years.
lead_paragraph: An appeals panel said the court needed time to consider the larger issues surrounding the death sentence of a man whose lawyers say he suffered from schizophrenia for years before killing his in-laws.

headline.main: Execution Stayed in Case of Mental Illness Claim in Texas
headline.print_headline: Execution Stayed in Case of Mental Illness Claim
